content.p: Below are some Greasemonkey user scripts I wrote. Greasemonkey is an extension for Firefox which allows users to alter the content and behavior of any website through user scripts which work inside the browser.
For a large collection of other Greasemonkey user scripts, visit the Greasemonkey Wiki.

To install a user script, you need Greasemonkey (and for Greasemonkey, you need Firefox). After that, open the user script in your browser, examine the source to convince yourself I'm not stealing your passwords or anything, and select 'Install User Script' from the 'Tools' menu in Firefox. Accept the default configuration and go to the website the user script is written for.
After Greasemonkey is installed, a small monkey icon will appear in the lower-right corner of Firefox. You can click on it to temporarily disable or enable all Greasemonkey user scripts.
To edit a user script after installation (e.g. to change some configuration settings), locate the *.user.js files in your Firefox profile directory, somewhere deep down like this:
Open the user script file in an editor and save it after you made your changes. Refreshing the webpage is enough for the changes to take effect.
All user scripts on this page are Open Source and licensed under the new BSD License. This means you can pretty much do with them whatever you like.

Tracking down and reading unread posts on Lambda the Ultimate started to annoy me quite a bit. Lambda Skipper adds a direct jump to the top-most unread post for each node to the Recent posts overview. It also adds links to skip to the next unread post in the node view (in top-to-bottom order rather than chronological order).

img.alt: Skip to next unread post link of Lambda Skipper

content.p: I read Lambda The Ultimate by going to the Recent posts overview and loading all 'top-most unread post' links in background tabs. For each tab, I go through all unread posts using the 'next unread post' links.

Nu Compact rewrites the four 'main' stories with pictures on the nu.nl frontpage to regular links. Most of the time the picture has nothing to do with the story anyway, and this allows us to have the entire frontpage in one screen.

content.p: BBTis can be configured to automatically log in to TisVU (if you're not already). To enable this option, locate the BBTis user script after installation and adjust the configuration section to your needs (as explained above).
TisNiks is a small collection of Javascript functions for querying the TisVU application of the Vrije Universiteit. It is not a user script itself, but meant to be used in user scripts.
